reviewText:
Puzzle games in my eyes need a few things to be entertaining, addicting tests of your wits. They should be easy to pick up, with basic rules that don’t require lengthy tutorials or wordy instructions to understand. They ought to be dynamic, built on a framework that can be easily reworked into a continual stream of interesting puzzles that don’t become repetitive despite being similar if not identical in design. And lastly I prefer them to be easy to pick up and put down, like a coffee table book that you can spend a few minutes or hours passing the time with, then set it back down for an unknown amount of time and still find it just as enjoyable the next time you look at it.

LYNE seems to have unknowingly looked into my head and designed itself around these ideals, forming into a simple but exemplary brain teaser that I fell in love with from the very first screen. It’s a relaxing yet engrossing experience that excels at putting you in a zen like state as you clear puzzles and feel especially clever each and every time you do.

In essence, LYNE can best be thought of as a nonlinear connect-the-dots. You’re given two points that you must connect, while going through all of the requisite points between them, but the order in which you do so is entirely up to you. There isn’t necessarily only one way to solve a puzzle, and this freedom is but one reason I find LYNE hugely refreshing compared to so many other puzzle games. As you progress you begin to deal with multiple colors, points you must repeatedly run through, and more complex designs that have you connecting lines like a mad cartographer, which from the outside looking on would seem highly complex and difficult.

But, it never feels that way when you’re playing. The fundamentals are so basic that it feels almost innate, like you’ve already been doing this for years. Something about LYNE clicked with me instantly, allowing me to breeze through level after level without an abundance of difficulty but leaving that satisfying feeling of accomplishment when you flex your frontal lobe and solve a problem. The soothing ambient sounds and mellow colors do well to elicit a calm mindset, making this an ideal way to let loose of your tension and unwind as you focus on the problem at hand.

In a similar way that many treat Sudoku and crossword puzzles, LYNE has something of a habitual quality; something you can go back to every day to help keep you sharp and relax after the more trying events of a day. The structure is tailor made for this style of play, with puzzles grouped into sets that are just long enough to be rewarding but not fatiguing. Random daily puzzles (though you’d never know that do to them being just as well designed as the base sets) provide consistent new content, at which point I can think of little more I could ask for.

Brilliant, Thomas Wowker, brilliant.

reviewText:
This puzzle game is a surprising joy to play. Its really interesting and feels fresh from other games that I've played. What does it involve? Drawing lines... yep that easy. You have colored shapes, each set of colored shapes has 2 'cap' shapes, where you can either start or end the colored line. So you start on a green box / triangle, then click and drag your mouse between the matching color shapes making lines. All shapes need to be connected and can only be connected to once. The lines can only go in eight directions from each shape. Its super easy. Then the game adds different colored shapes, so you've got green lines and red lines. So what's the catch? You can't cross the lines. So where's the challenge? Eventually directional octagonal shapes get added, these are neutral blocks that you're able to attach multiple lines on in 8 directions, no matter what color the line is, just as long as you don't cross the lines. It starts with simple octagon blocks that need you to connect to them twice.... then three times and so on.

Can you lose? Nope. You have as much time as you want. You can't fail, if you do the puzzle inaccurately it just has a little red line around the box you forgot. Then you keep going. If you screw up, just click one of the cap shapes to delete the lines or back track your lines by clicking and dragging backward to remove the line you just made. If you ever get truly stumped, you can back out of that puzzle and go to any one of the 25 other puzzles in the group. You'll unlock a few groups at a time, so you'll always have 75 puzzles to chose from. The game goes in succession, once you complete one puzzle its immediately to the next. There is a legitimate sense of satisfaction when I complete a puzzle that I was stumped on. Not just that, but eventually I found myself thinking of the dynamics of these puzzles and realizing where I should start first.

The game has 25 puzzles per group and groups A - Z. 25 * 26 levels = 650 levels. Is that not enough for you? Well then there are daily levels with 25 levels of A B C making for 75 daily levels. The daily levels are considerably more difficult than the default puzzles. Its a nice way to keep fresh content and keep people in the game.

If you don't like puzzle games, avoid this. The first 50 levels are understandably easy, but they do get more challenging. It is a soothing game and the puzzles get complex, but still easy and simple.

reviewText:
Brain melter! - 10/10
Introduction:
LYNE is a game for people, who love to use their brain even in the spare time. It's perfectly suited for everyone, who wants to play just some minutes or long sessions up to 2 hours. Your task is simple. Connect the two main knots for each color and all knots of the color on the way between both. All knots have to be used. You're not allowed to cross lines or to use the same way, you've already used before. Sounds simple, right? But it can become very challenging, if you have to deal with several colors and neutral knots, which have to be used multiple times. Your brain can really melt in longer sessions and you should seriously stop, if you're starting to see lines, where they aren't supposed to be.

The game has 2 game modes: chapter mode (26 chapters (A-Z) with 25 levels per chapter) and daily challenges (3 chapters with 25 levels per chapter), which will be random generated every day.

Friendly advice: If you're not able to solve a specific level in 20 minutes, then give it a rest, do something else instead and pick it up later again. You will see it with a fresh view and maybe solve it in 10-30 seconds, at least this was my experience.


Pro:
easy to learn
650 levels (26 chapters with 25 levels per chapter)
3 random generated daily challenges every day with 25 levels per challenge
very easy up to extremely challenging levels
very high replayability
extremely addicting
unlockable color themes for some visual variation
easy undo function
no time limit
price

Contra:
the audio effects don't vary that much and can become annoying in longer game sessions

Conclusion:
Excellent game for a good brain workout. It's very cheap, addicting, easy to learn, offers difficulty levels in form of different chapters for everyone and has a very high replayability. If you love to use your brain, then LYNE will be perfect for you. Not recommendable for stones. Absolutely recommendable for everyone with a working human brain.


10/10 - would draw another line anytime

LYNE can best be described as a minimalist puzzle game.

Essentially it is a series of logic puzzles generated on a grid, consisting of coloured nodes and permeable gears.  Each puzzle must be solved on the fly by connecting paths from one primary node to another through the same coloured nodes and transitional gears.  The goal is to ensure that all nodes and all the slots on each gear are used in the eventual solution.

There are twenty-five individual puzzles grouped into twenty-six sets, which grow in depth and complexity the greater the progress made.  As you can imagine the puzzles start off deliberately simple allowing players to grasp the basic elements of gameplay.  Later puzzles require an ever increasing amount of convoluted paths to be drawn in order to use all the available nodes and gear slots.  In addition the game also generates a set of daily time-limited puzzles which vary in complexity and must be finished each day or they disappear until they are generated sometime in the future.

Finding the solution to each puzzle can take between a few seconds and a few minutes depending on your ability. If you become stuck a combination of trial and error will eventually lead you to your goal.  If you really dislike puzzle-solving take heart, for what I found truly amazing about LYNE is that it that solutions become intuitive.  Drawing the correct paths take on an almost organic feel.  Someone on the forums said that 'it feels like LYNE rewires the way your brain works,' and it does feel like that.

Despite the graphics feeling simplistic they are cleanly drawn and totally appropriate.  While there is no music to speak of the game uses a series of medolic sounds with every mouse stroke that rise in frequency the the faster the connections are made.  Together these sounds have an almost hypnotic quality which Im sure sublimally urges you on to complete the next objective.

If you dont like solving puzzle or find that your brain just isnt suited to play such games then this might be an exception.  It is such a wonderful distraction from the plethora of online shooters, RTS and RPG/adventure games out there that you should really give it a go.  LYNE is everything it says it is on the store page and worth the cheap price.  Glad I made this purchase.

LYNE is probably one of the best (if not the best) valued casual puzzle games on Steam. reviewText:
This is a fun and inexpensive logic puzzler.  The gameplay is basic and increasing in difficulty as you unlock the latter levels. The player must connect the lines without intersecting, unless through a junction box, to go from a start place to the end place.  All pieces must be connected and in some instances a certain number of intersections must occur through junction boxes.  There is also a dailly puzzle generator that can be used to generate puzzles of differing difficulties randomly each day.

Achievements are based upon completing sets of 25 puzzles.  There are 26 sets going from A-Z with an achievement for each one plus achievements for doing certain amounts of dailly puzzles. An achievement is also given for opening different color pallets.  Which are opened by completing puzzles.

My personal experience of the gameplay it was fun right at first.  Then got a lil old, but, I was glad I stuck with it because over time my mind seemed to become more attuned to how the lines had to flow in order to complete the puzzles.

This is a gem of a puzzle game that's easily worth more than the asking price.

The puzzle mechanic is very simple but with a surprising amount of depth.  The first few levels are quite easy, employing the common pattern of introducing game mechanics gradually.  But the difficulty ramps up dramatically at a certain point.  The pacing is nice, too, as you get a few easier levels as a break in between some very difficult puzzles.

The daily puzzles are a great addition, too.  Even after you finish the game, you can keep coming back for new content.

The soundtrack is relaxing, distantly reminiscent of games like Osmos.  It's great game to relax with after a hard day of work.

reviewText:
Now THIS is how you make a puzzle game! Both elegant in its simplicity and devious in its complexity, LYNE is a beautiful blend of pick-up-and-play accessibility and fair, reasonable challenge that pretty much never punishes and only rewards. I'm not sure of the exact terminology of every element of the game, so I'm just going to have to wing it and hope it all makes sense...

The easiest way to probably explain it is to say it's a game of join the dots. There are three main coloured shapes, or nodes, scattered across a gridded board, green triangles, red squares and blue diamonds (at least by default, the colour palette can be unlocked and changed throughout the game), with a start and end point for each shape. The object being to drag a line that joins each point whilst also passing through all the faded out nodes of the same shape. So the green line can only pass through the faded green nodes, and so on. There are also neutral nodes that any line can pass through which act as intersections for the different coloured lines. With the exception of these neutral nodes, each node can only be passed through once, either vertically, horizontally or diagonally, and a line can never cross through another line. So, basically, connect each start and end point, and fill in the board along the way. As with most puzzle games, it can sound way more complicated in writing than it really is, but within thirty seconds of actual play you'll perfectly understand exactly how the whole thing works.

The game's first triumph is in teaching itself to the player. With the way it introduces each element of play, the only actions you'll be able to perform are the ones it wants you to learn, further reinforced by brief phases of repetition and minor variation. It won't take long for the series of light bulbs to come on over your head with each new method of covering the board that you learn and you'll soon find yourself steamrolling your way through the opening few stages.

There are 26 sets of puzzles corrosponding to each letter of the alphabet, with each set containing 25 individual puzzles for a total of 650... yeah, you read that right, 650 puzzles. On top of that there are also random daily sets, but unless I'm mistaken, they at least appeared to me to be a mix of various puzzles from the main sets. It's hard to say how long it takes to complete, given that each player will spend a vastly different amount of time depending on their personal skill level, but I reckon about 30 hours would be a reasonable guess, give or take a few hours.

What I really love about this game is how success or failure rests solely in the hands of the player's own determination. With no time limit and no way to technically lose (you either finish a puzzle or you walk away from it), the game is a test of perseverance more than anything. There are a few tricks you can learn to criss-cross your way around a board, but really you'll have to poke and prod at everything and experiment with different routes before honing in on the solution. But rarely will the game leave you hanging, and it'll usually hint as to where you should at least start before working your way out, and from there on it's a gradual process of elimination. It also helps that many puzzles will have multiple methods to solve them, so there is some flexibility in play.

Topping everything off is a slick, clean aesthetic that's minimalist but still appealing. I wasn't a massive fan of the audio as the pinging chimes gradually grated against me and I instead opted to play my own music in the background the entire time, but that's a very minor gripe given how it doesn't really serve any fuctional role in the game play and you can easily live without it. But what I was a massive fan off was the price which is the sweet little cherry on top that should be the final nudge to any fence-sitters still not entirely sure whether or not they should pick this up. Protip, you should.

Finally 100% completed this game, a lot because the awesome looking letter/pattern achievements that you can display in your showcase on your profile. Yes, I admit that was one of the reasons why I got the game in its first place. But behind all the letters and showcasing there is actually a nice little game, if not 100% when it comes to enjoyment. I will still reccomend it, though, it is a really good game that is not too expensive even when it's not on sale.

So what's the good things besides the achievements? The simple concept of connecting shapes, or dots if you want over all the letters in the alphabet  plus extra levels that changes every day (Daily), and a nice bonus that you can change the colour pallette of the background and the shapes. 25 levels per letter set will keep you entertained(or frustrated) throughout the hours, days, week... depending on how fast you complete. There are excellent guides however should you get stuck somewhere. Also, a huge plus for the silence; no annoying music, just the occasional sounds when you connect lines and makes it to the next level.

The only downside is the later letter sets when you get the same colour and shapes on every level, sometimes it gets a bit monotonous to do a lot at once. It's getting better once you are closer to the end, though.

Looking at both sides of the games, it is a really good one and well worth its price so get it whether it's on sale or not. Not much bad aside from above, either and if those would have had a bit more variety I would probably make huge shoutouts about getting it. Do get it however.

reviewText:
Brought to us by Australian indie developer Thomas Bowker, LYNE is a minimalist puzzle game that tasks you with connecting sets of colored shapes, without crossing or re-tracing any lines along the way. If it sounds simple, that’s because it is by design; LYNE claims to be “deceptively simple” yet “infinitely complex”. But does it do enough to set itself apart from the ever-growing library of puzzlers competing for gamers’ attention?

LYNE is designed to be as streamlined and polished as possible. Your first moments with the game set the tone for the entire experience as you’re met with crisp lines, pastel colors and gentle sounds, making for a very refined appearance. The menus are easily navigated as well, and overall everything feels calculated and elegant. The puzzles themselves are divided into lettered sets of 25, and completing a set earns you anywhere from one to five points, depending on the difficulty. As you accumulate points, you’ll unlock additional level sets and color palettes. There are hundreds of puzzles pre-loaded, so there's no shortage of challenges to tackle!

The puzzles start off easy, acquainting you with the controls and basic gameplay with a few stylized visual prompts. However, after the first level set you’re on your own. Still, the difficulty curve is gentle enough to welcome even those who have never tried a puzzle game before, while still appealing to even the most hardcore of puzzle masters. No lives and no time limit means the pressures of performance and progression are removed, placing the focus on the player’s experience with the game. There is a surprising amount of variety in the puzzle design, all while only ever using four different shapes. It’s not overcomplicated, and if you ever feel yourself growing tired of looking at the same colored shapes in different arrangements you can simply change the color palette for a fresh visual experience. Completing a puzzle sends it sliding off to the left to be replaced by another, and a total lack of load time helps LYNE maintain a superb flow.

As excellent as the puzzle design is, the secret of LYNE lies in its audio. Ambient and echoing but never obtrusive, the soft tones that emanate from each connected shape combine with the minimalist visuals to create an impressively immersive and calming environment. I often ended up playing it after a stressful day, and found relief in its gentle, tranquil presentation. That combined with the satisfaction of puzzle completion means it easy to lose yourself in LYNE.

At $2.99, its price is a bit steep for a seemingly simple puzzle game. It’s a shame so many people will pass over LYNE without a second thought just because it’s not free or under a buck, because it truly does offer a unique and immersive experience.

LYNE is a great game not only for its clever puzzles, but for the soul soothing elegance it emanates throughout the experience. Don’t let the price stop you: this is a game worth owning. If you’re looking for the next Tetris you won’t find it here, but LYNE distances itself from the frantic and competitive nature of other games in the genre for a gentle yet challenging experience that is perfect for nearly every gamer.

Highly Recommended

I think LYNE's strong point lies in its simplicity and the way the few elements work symbiotically with each other. Let's take a look at why I consider LYNE a successful experiment in subtractive design.

It's a casual game, first of all. It's not meant for scores or competitiveness, it gives away a relaxing atmosphere. reviewText:
A simple, yet stylish way to enhance your profile

An exceptional puzzle game that has the right difficulty curve, addictive gameplay and a amazing minimalist design. To put the icing on the cake it has easy achievements which can be used to spell what you'd like using the achievement showcase. You also get 3/5 card drops for playing.

LYNE has hours of relaxing content with 650 puzzles to solve and the additon of 50 daily puzzles. Not to mention that it also has a soothing, dynamic sound track which works well with the simplistic visuals. The objective of LYNE is simple; Try to connect A to B without intersecting the other lines and fulfilling the requirements to complete the level. After completing all the levels in a set, you will unlock an achievement plus another set. After a while you will also unlock different colour palettes as an added bonus for completing sets. The puzzles start to get harder as you continue through the game as the puzzles are more complex and new mechanics are introduced, however the game does get repetitve at times, despite the difficulty curve.

To sum it up, this is a great game to kill some time or to play whilst watching something. It's pretty cheap too, and you can find a 50% off coupon somewhere, but is well worth the full price in my opinion.

LYNE is a logic puzzle game where you attempt to connect all shapes of similar type/color with a single line. Each tile can connect to any active tiles of the same shape (and a few which allow for multiple lines to pass through) in any adjacent or diagonal direction.

It takes this relatively simple mechanic and has a nearly endless supply of levels - each group has 25 levels, and there's 26 groups included in the game, along with a daily feature which has up to three groups of varying difficulty.

This is a game best played in short bursts, as too much of it at one time can become tiresome. That being said, for those short periods of time, it ends up being a very relaxing and satisfying puzzle game, with some of the harder levels leaving you scratching your head for a great deal of time.

LYNE is a simple, yet challenging puzzle game, made by Aussie developer Thomas Bowker, this game very easily shows off the creativity of today.

LYNE has you staring at your computer for hours on end, trying to figure out how to connect those final lines. The game starts off easy, only having one colour and an easy path to go over, but quickly develops in difficulty. By about set 'F', the game has multiple colours, all needing to go somewhere. The simplicity of the graphics and music is done excellently. The whole game is about connecting and drawing lines, but at the same time, covering the entire board and not hitting any other colour. When you finally see the answer, you will realise that it's been staring you in the face the entire time. On some levels, there are these overlapping type squares that allow you to put multiple colours through it at once, although, this is not always useful, seeing as you need to fill that completely as well before the level is finished.

This game is PERFECT for casual gamers and people who like to spend time on things. LYNE has no time limit so you can spend all day trying to figure out how to bring that red line to the other red area... By the time you finish one set, there's another one. Each set has 25 levels. There are 26 level sets, all have their own names. If you could call a single letter a name. So, 25 times (*) 26 = a whopping 650 words, all for a small price of $3 (to be more precise, $2.99) and during the sales, you can get this game for an even smaller price of $0.49, which is a massive bargain. I mean, 49 cents for a game that will leave you addicted for hours on end, and that's what LYNE is all about, a simple, yet almost perfect puzzle game.

This is a fantastic puzzle game about connecting all the same color dots together in lines as well as filling in the non-color specific blocks.  It's a nice little bit of brain training with both fixed levels to work through and daily levels.   The base levels unlock in sets as you complete them as well as do the first two days of daily puzzles.  There are 25 puzzles per set, with 650 puzzles total in the fixed puzzles.   That may sound like a lot, but some puzzles will take seconds to complete while others could take a minute or more so it won't take more than a couple days of regular play to get through them all.  But the daily puzzles tend to add up to another 350 puzzles per week if you play them all.   So even if you blow through the main puzzles in a couple days, there's plenty to come back to.  In addition to all of this there's a sort of meta game of collecting triangles as you play.  Each set is ranked by difficulty with 1 to 5 triangles and if you complete all the puzzles in the set you get those number of triangles added to a master score.   It's not a big thing, but I'm curious to find out what happens at 999 triangles earned out of 999.  I'm about a 120 away from there on the iOS version (so maybe a week and a half more worth of daily puzzles).  It'll take a lot longer on this version since I started it only recently.\n\nIn any event this game is excellent.  Not many puzzle games get me coming back to them... which makes this a pretty special game.  Plus I don't review games if I don't feel they are worth my time. LYNE has you staring at your computer for hours on end, trying to figure out how to connect those final lines. The game starts off easy, only having one colour and an easy path to go over, but quickly develops in difficulty. By about set 'F', the game has multiple colours, all needing to go somewhere. The simplicity of the graphics and music is done excellently. The whole game is about connecting and drawing lines, but at the same time, covering the entire board and not hitting any other colour. When you finally see the answer, you will realise that it's been staring you in the face the entire time. On some levels, there are these overlapping type squares that allow you to put multiple colours through it at once, although, this is not always useful, seeing as you need to fill that completely as well before the level is finished.

This game is PERFECT for casual gamers and people who like to spend time on things. LYNE has no time limit so you can spend all day trying to figure out how to bring that red line to the other red area... By the time you finish one set, there's another one. Each set has 25 levels. There are 26 level sets, all have their own names. If you could call a single letter a name. So, 25 times (*) 26 = a whopping 650 words, all for a small price of $3 (to be more precise, $2.99) and during the sales, you can get this game for an even smaller price of $0.49, which is a massive bargain. I mean, 49 cents for a game that will leave you addicted for hours on end, and that's what LYNE is all about, a simple, yet almost perfect puzzle game.

If all of that hasn't persuaded you to buy this game yet, there's trading cards and steam achievements as well.

This game was really fun for the first few sets.  Then, it started to get a bit harder.  I wanted to write things out in my achievement showcase though, and I didn't want to just use Steam Achievement Manager or look up a guide.  That would more or less make the game a waste of money.

After around six hours of this game over the course of two sessions, I started to get a severe case of the Tetris Effect.  Every time I closed my eyes, I would start connecting shapes together.  In the days that followed, my dreams consisted entirely of connecting shapes together and solving puzzles.

I started to become frustrated with everyday life.  Why couldn't I connect shapes together in real life?  Why didn't connecting shapes together in my head solve my real world problems?

That was a month and a half ago.  I have since picked the game up again, but I'm using a guide this time.  It's a compromise between having no fun and the shape-infested hell I was living in when I first started playing.  There are also randomly generated puzzles that are just as good as the normal ones, so if I start seeing shapes again, I can always just cheat all of the achievements and play the random levels afterward.

Let it be known that I beat sets A-F and got partway through G before losing my mind.  I urge that if you want to play this game legitimately...at least pace yourself.  Otherwise, you could end up like me.

Edit:  Today, scared of returning to shape-infested hell, I cheated the achievements.

reviewText:
Overall: Pretty good
Difficulty: Mostly very low

Comments:
- The second section of this article (http://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2015/01/22/how-to-make-a-puzzle-game/) is a good discussion that touches on why I think this is only a pretty good puzzle game, not a good one.

Likes:

Dislikes:
- Monotonous. This game is based only on a single idea: draw lines through all the nodes.  All of the puzzles are just reconfigurations of this same basic problem, and they are all solved using the same lines of reasoning.  Nothing new is introduced to make the puzzles more interesting or varied.
- Straightforward and lacks depth -- any difficulty comes from the number of possible paths, not from any depth of gameplay
- The number of possible paths encourages a trial and error approach to puzzle solving, rather than a more analytical, calculated approach
- Not challenging until around set U (the 21st set of puzzles, out of 26 total sets).  Many puzzles are trivial and could be removed without losing anything of value

Lyne is a soothing, feel good puzzle game that is simple, minimalistic, and enjoyable as can be. Lyne's strongest point is that there's almost always variations in the answers; it's never limited to one exact solution. This gives players the opportunity to really be creative and try out many different setups within a single level.\n\nIf you enjoy relaxing puzzles, then this is a game worth getting.

A simple, fun, and challenging game. When describing the game, by saying that you're trying to connect two end points and travel through nodes a particular amount of times, it sounds like it would be boring. The game is designed in such a way that it's so polished and plays so smooth, that it makes that simple idea fulfilling.

It's a great way to waste 15 minutes here and there, and there are 550 levels (25*26), and they can be completed in less than 10 seconds, or stump you for a while. You are fortunately able to work on any of the 25 levels at a time, based on what stage (letter of the alphabet) you've gotten to, so that you aren't necessarily going to be stuck on 1 level with nothing else to play. The downside is that you have to wait to beat stage A to get to B, B to get to C, and so forth.

The game did go a bit downhill after taking a little too long to boost the difficulty up, and it did feel like it went from medium to hard in a single jump from stage S to stage T (at least in my opinion). I'm now working on stage V and the puzzles tend to take >1 minutes each. I feel like stage T onwards are where this game shines, and it's a shame you have to beat a fair amount of easy puzzles to get there, but that wouldn't stop me from recommending the game.

Lyne’s all about forming pathways between like-colored shapes positioned on a grid — you’re essentially joining the dots, but are restricted to 90- and 45-degree angles. As you work on each puzzle, abstract noises pleasingly chirp away in the background, confirming every connection like a panpipe-playing robot.\n\nIt all feels very pleasant, and at first it’s disarmingly simple. Soon, though, the game bares its teeth. Shapes are positioned in a manner that makes successful pathways between them all far from immediately obvious, especially once you realize paths cannot cross. Junction boxes add to the task, demanding you enter them a specific number of times to illuminate all their lights. Failure merely results in a sadly pulsating red outline and the realization you must rethink, experiment, and iterate.

reviewText: A puzzle made with simple design but with exciting and challenging levels to master.

A pretty cool puzzle game. Minimalistic in style, your task is simply to connect shapes together using lines according to some simple rules. Its quite playable, good for what it is. The later level sets do get quite tough and the whole game can take quite a long time to complete.

A surprisingly intuitive and easy to pick up puzzle game that introduces devilish complexity and a frankly staggeringly large number of levels (I'm an hour and a half in and I've only completed 75 out of 650 puzzles), coupled with the fact that at the time of review LYNE is on sale for just $0.89 means that it's an unbeatable buy. I have purchased several hundred games and LYNE is hands down bar none the best value for money.\n\nWith a pleasant simplistic design that lets you get straight into the puzzle solving (which can take anywhere between half a second and half an hour per puzzle, depending on the difficulty), it's something that I wish we saw more of in modern video games. One of my largest gripes with puzzle games is when you're forced to sit through a several minute tutorial with mandatory wait times or - even worse! - having to watch the game do it for you at an antagonisingly slow pace. LYNE has no such tutorial. Instead, you learn the mechanics of the game through a series of a slowly ramping difficulty curve, and if the puzzles are too easy at the start (which they probably will be for anyone who's played similar games before), they take less than a second to complete and the next one loads rapidly, with no gimmicky congratulations!' screen or long celebration animations. reviewText: Simple, elegant and the trailer does set the expectations perfectly. I've completed over 200 levels, and I've really enjoyed it so far! Highly reccomended game for a price that's like a steal even before a sale!

An insanely simple puzzle game that becomes insanely difficult. There are 25 levels per alphabet letter, each getting slighly harder. There are 650 total levels + infinite daily levels. Plenty of content!

It's a bit slow as you start off as the first 50 or so puzzles are just a bit too easy.

I would recommend this game on Android / iOS over PC. It's a perfect game for commuting.
